Scene: HBO title
The Hound is in a community
Comparison:
In the books, the Hound's fate remains unknown; he does not appear after Arya leaves him to die. His reappearance is taken from a fan theory based on clues in a chapter from the fourth novel, "A Feast for Crows".

There is no book character named Septon Ray. He is based on two book characters whom Brienne meets in A Feast for Crows - Septon Meribald and the Elder Brother.

Scene: Opening Credits / Title Sequence
Why the Hound keeps going
Comparison: In the books, the Hound's fate remains unknown; he does not appear after Arya leaves him to die. His reappearance is taken from a fan theory based on clues in a chapter from the fourth novel, "A Feast for Crows".

Scene: Margaery is converted to the new way
Margaery speaks to Lady Olenna
Comparison:
In the books, Willas Tyrell, not Loras, is the heir of Highgarden.
Septa Unella watches Cersei while she is imprisoned, not Margaery. Cersei is the one who threatens to kill her.

Scene: Jon convinces the wildlings to ally with him
Cersei tries to talk Lady Olenna out of leaving King's Landing
Jaime and Bronn arrive at the siege of Riverrun
Comparison: In the books, the High Sparrow has nothing to do with Jaime's mission to conquer Riverrun. Jaime leads nearly 1,000 soldiers to Riverrun, not 8,000. Ilyn Payne, not Bronn, accompanies him. Jaime never promises Bronn anything.

Scene: Jaime takes over command of the siege
Comparison:
Ryman Frey commands the Frey troops which besiege Riverrun. He is the one who threatens to hang Edmure, and is beaten by Jaime. No one threatens to slit Edmure's throat.

Lame Lother does not take part in the siege of Riverrun. Daven Lannister builds siege machines before Jaime arrives.

Jaime orders to release Edmure from the gallows after, not before the parley with Blackfish.

Scene: Jon talks to Lady Mormont of Bear Island
Comparison: The fate of Maege Mormont and Galbart Glover is uncertain. Before going to the Twins, Robb sent them on a mission to the north. It is unknown what happened to them. In the fifth novel, her second daughter Alysane comments that her sisters Jorelle and Lyra are with their mother, but does not say where.

Scene: Kingslayer and the Blackfish parley
Comparison:
During the parley, Jaime offers Brynden to resolve the siege by a duel between their champions. Brynden refuses.

Brynden states that he agreed to parley because he wanted to hear Jaime's excuses for not returning Sansa and Arya as promised, and also to see his stump. Jaime offers to settle the matter by single combat between them. Brynden laughs at the prospect, but refuses, as it would gain him nothing but the pleasure of killing Jaime. Jaime thinks wistfully that such a duel would have been great once, similar to a comment made in the series by Areo Hotah.

Scene: Lord Glover refuses to join the war
Comparison:
The fate of Maege Mormont and Galbart Glover is uncertain. Before going to the Twins, Robb sent them on a mission to the north. It is unknown what happened to them. In the fifth novel, her second daughter Alysane comments that her sisters Jorelle and Lyra are with their mother, but does not say where.

Jared Frey, not Robett Glover (who is loyal to the Starks), speaks ill about Robb.

Scene: Yara asks Theon to man up
Comparison:
It is Victarion Greyjoy, not Asha and Theon (who are held captive at Stannis's camp) who arrives at Volantis on the way to Meereen.

Euron does not hunt Asha and Theon.
Theon says the sentence "The gods are not done with me" about himself.

Yara Greyjoy (called "Asha" in the books) is not bisexual, and never has a sexual encounter with a female.

Scene: Sansa tells Jon they need more men
Sansa writes a letter
Three men on horses try to extort the community
Comparison:
There is no book character named Septon Ray. He is based on two book characters whom Brienne meets in A Feast for Crows - Septon Meribald and the Elder Brother.

Septon Meribald does not give a speech about wars and broken men in public, but tells it to Brienne.

Scene: The Hound thinks they should protect themselves
Arya books passage back to Westeros
Arya is stabbed by the Waif in disguise
The Hound finds the community all dead
Comparison:
The Hound's fate remains unknown; he does not appear after Arya leaves him to die in the third book.

None of the Brotherhood have gone rogue and killed harmless villagers.
